⁎ Corresponding authors. This review focuses on apatite based catalysts, which are widely used in a large spectra of chemical reactions: oxidation, reduction, formation of CC, CO, C-S, and CN bond, cycloadditions and multi-component reaction. Up to date reviews were mainly devoted to the catalysed reactions themselves, which were described in details. Nevertheless, the intimated nature of the catalysts used, which are obtained from various preparation techniques has deserved less attention. This review is a first tentative classification of the apatite based catalysts where stoichiometric or not apatites as well as modified ones by cation or anion substitution in their structure or surface, act as catalyst, as well as apatites acting as catalyst support. In each case the specific role of the apatite as well as the synergic effect between the catalytic entity and the apatitic support will be discussed. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Apatites Modified-apatites Catalysis Structure-activity Surfaces 1 Introduction The use of apatites (Ap) in heterogeneous catalysis is widely documented in many reviews [1–6] that focus on the chemical reactions that these catalysts allow. The range of reactions described is wide: there are reactions of oxidation, reduction, formation of CC, CO, C-S and CN bonds, cycloadditions, multi-component reactions… The main feature of apatitic surfaces is related to their acid-base properties, which are essential in organic synthesis catalysis. Modulation of the synthesis parameters of apatites, as well as their ability toward substitution allows their versatility in terms of composition, stoichiometry and morphology to be used to highlight the relationships that exist between structure and acid-base properties. Indeed, at a macroscopic level, stoichiometry, represented by the Ca/P ratio, and morphology are the two key parameters controlling the base properties of those materials. For example, lowering of the Ca/P ratio leads to a decrease in the basicity and increases the acidic properties of the surface. With a low non-stoichiometric Ca/P ratio of 1.50, hydroxyapatite acts as an acid catalyst with the existence of basic sites. In contrast, with a stoichiometric ratio of 1.67, hydroxyapatite acts as a basic catalyst while acid sites are still present. Therefore, when dealing with the catalytic properties of a material, it is necessary to investigate the surface composition, taking into consideration the fact that the composition of the bulk and the surface are not the same. With regards to apatites, this problem has been reported by several authors. If, in general, the catalysis reactions are well identified, on the other hand the description of the catalysts is often less complete and grey areas persist. We have found in the literature no less than eleven terms to describe their synthesis: “impregnation”, "substitution”, “incorporation” “immobilization”, or to define the final materials obtained: “doped apatite”, “modified apatite”, “surface modified apatite”, “grafted apatite”, “adsorbed (nanoparticles) on apatites”, “encapsulated catalysts”, “supported catalysts on apatite”. These terms shed little light on the reality of the catalysts obtained and the particular role that apatite plays whether as a simple support and / or as an active catalyst in synergy with the entity supported or integrated into the apatitic structure? In addition, several designs concern the production and properties of these catalytic materials: “binding”, “deposition precipitation”, “exchange” and “concerto-effect”. Our review intends to bring some order to this rich field covering the synthesis, structure and properties of all the catalysts based on apatites. This leads us to examine the fundamental features of apatites, their syntheses, their structures and their properties and especially their surface properties which are intimately linked to their compositions and their methods of production. We will examine in particular the re-precipitation dissolution process which plays a decisive role in ionic exchange at the apatite level, an exchange which plays a large role in obtaining catalysts based on apatites. We will also show the nature of the interactions between organic molecules and the surface of apatites. From this base, we will review the main Ca-, Sr- and Ba- stoichiometric or not Ap and modified Ap used as catalysts. In the case of CaAp, where Ca2+ ions are substituted in the structure by Mn+ cations, we describe them following the order of the periodic classification. 2 Generality on the composition and structure of apatite materials Stoichiometric calcium hydroxyapatites HAp and fluorapatites FAp are of general formula Ca10(PO4)6(OH)2 and Ca10(PO4)6(F)2, respectively. The name “apatite” introduced by the German geologist A. G. Werner designates a large family of natural compounds and their synthetic analogues. The crystal structure of these compounds is characterized by the presence of tetrahedral anionic groups XO4 with X = P, Si, Ge, As associated with cations M with M = Ca, Ba, Sr, Pb, K, Na and potentially additional anions Z such as F, Cl, O, OH or water H2O leading to a general chemical formula M5(XO4)3Zq. Apatite compounds crystallize in the hexagonal system, point group 6/m. The crystal structure of apatite was first solved in 1930 by Mehmel [7] and Naray-Szabo [8] and the archetype crystal structure belongs to the P63/m space group (n° 176). The unit-cell parameters are usually close to 9.3 – 9.6 for a and 6.7 – 6.9 for the c parameter. The atomic sites and atomic coordinates for archetype hydroxyapatite and fluorapatite [9] are given in Table 1 . Taking into account the atomic sites of the crystal structure and their occupation, the general chemical formula of apatite compounds can thus be written as follows: M(1)4M(2)6 [XO(1)O(2)O(3)2]6Z2. The crystal structure of archetype apatite consists of isolated [XO4] tetrahedra at z = ¼ and z = ¾ linked by M(1) cations and M(2) cations. M(1) cations are ninefold coordinated while M(2) cations are sevenfold coordinated. The symmetry of the M(1) site is C3 with 6 oxygen atoms nearest neighbours forming a triangular prism and 3 more distant oxygen atoms. The symmetry of the M(2) site is Cs with an environment consisting of O(1), O(2), 4xO(3) oxygen and additional oxygen from the hydroxyl group (or fluorine in the case of the fluoroapatite) (Fig. 1 ). It can be noted that some apatite type compounds also crystallize in subgroups of the P63/m space groups (P63, P-6 P-3, P3, P21/m or P21). In all cases, the major feature of the apatite structure is that the M(1)4(XO4)6 framework induces the presence of a c-axis tunnel which accommodates the M(2)O5 and Z entities. 3 Main synthetic routes towards apatitic materials Apatitic materials have found large scale application, particularly in medicine, and accordingly the number of studies of synthetic methods has been increased explosively [10–14]. The methods of synthesis of apatites largely determine their composition, structure and surface properties. 3.1 Dry methods Mechanochemical synthesis is based on mixing the starting compounds for a long-time in a high-energy mill. Mechanically induced chemical changes take place under the high load and strain rate conditions found at the contact points between the milling media. This method is also used for obtaining some substituted apatitic materials [15–20]. High temperature synthesis is performed by calcination of the mixed starting chemicals at high temperature 1000 - 1200 °C and is often used for the preparation of apatites single crystals. A complex HAp doping mechanism, mainly realized by an interstitial process combined with calcium substitution for the larger cations of the series (Mn2+, Fe3+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+ and Zn2+) leading to potentially calcium deficient HAp, has been described [21]. The thermal stability of apatites, particularly of substituted apatites, depends strongly on their chemical composition, ranging from 650 °C for Mg-carbonate apatites to 1200 °C for fluorapatites [22]. 3.2 Wet methods amongst inorganic calcium phosphate the thermodynamically most stable are compounds with an apatitic structure, particularly in an aqueous medium of pH ˃ 6–7 [23, 24]. Therefore, the most widely used method for apatite synthesis is wet precipitation. There are hundreds of variations described that differ in composition of starting solutions, additives, temperature, pH, processing time, drying conditions etc. The principal reaction for hydroxyapatite synthesis (eq. (1)) is: (1) 10 Ca2+ + 6 PO4 3− +2 OH− → Ca10(PO4)6(OH)2 The calcium ion (+ substitute cations) and phosphate ions (+ CO3 2−, SO4 2−, SiO4 4−) solutions are mixed in aqueous environment at pH ˃ 7. To regulate the size of the crystallites, temperature, solution concentration, solution addition rates, surfactant additives… can be used as adjusting parameters [25, 26]. Depending on the above mentioned parameters the resulting apatites differ mainly in crystals size, specific surface area (SSA), chemical composition (stoichiometry 1.6 ≤ Ca/P ≤ 1.7) and crystals surface properties/composition. For preparation of substituted apatites, which contain more than one cation in their structure, the substitutes, may either be added into the precipitation environment (co-precipitation) [27, 28] or Ap is immersed (impregnated) in a solution of substituting cation [29]. The main mechanisms of binding metal ions with apatites from solution (impregnation) are ion-exchange, surface adsorption and co-precipitation. The extent of metal sorption depends on the apatite characteristics as well as on the metal ion. Sorption conditions such as solution properties (pH, anionic composition, presence of chelating compounds and ions of other metals), temperature, contact time…are also important [30]. The hydrothermal method based on the same reaction is carried out at elevated temperature (T ˃ 100 °C) and pressure. Under these conditions the formation of apatite is faster and results in bigger and more regular crystals [14, 23,31]. 3.3 Others There are other synthetic methods where different approaches are used more rarely, such as microwave synthesis [32], ultrasonic [33], and high-pressure method or electrochemical deposition techniques. Combination of wet ball milling or the sol-gel technique for homogenization of components followed by combustion/heat treatment is also used [34]. Sol-gel apatite synthesis starts with mixing the components in an aqueous or organic solvent environment followed by formation of gel complexes and their solidification. The solid precursor xerogel is pyrolysed and calcined in air at a temperature of 800–1000 °C. Often intermediate grinding is needed to improve the contact of the gas and solid phases [35]. Ptáček [14] and Fihri et al. [1] have published detailed overviews concerning the sol-gel synthesis. 3.4 Synthetic methods vs structure and properties High temperature solid state synthesis products are characterized by high crystallinity and larger crystal size in comparison with those from mechano-chemical and wet precipitation methods. High crystallinity is also characteristic of Aps obtained by the hydrothermal method. The low temperature synthesis processes (lower than 100 °C) usually generate nano-crystalline non-stoichiometric apatites [13]. Wet precipitation often results in non-stoichiometry that is explained by vacancies in both Ca and OH sites, concomitantly to the substitution of PO4 3− ions by HPO4 2− or CO3 2−, particularly at the crystal surface [36]. Apatites prepared at higher temperatures have compositions that are closer to stoichiometry (in the case of precipitation in basic medium). 3.5 Benefits and limitations of the different synthetic methods All solid state reactions are time and energy consuming. The main advantage of the mechano-chemical method is the simplicity and low cost, but due to the need to sustain the harsh conditions, the technique is only suited to producing small volumes of materials (a few hundred grams of powder) [14]. In the case of solid state high temperature synthesis the consumption of energy is high and it results in seriously aggregated products but well-crystallized large size crystals are obtained. Solid state synthesis products often contain other phases and crystal sizes and the shapes of the product are difficult to regulate. In sol-gel synthesis the homogeneity and the stoichiometry of the product are well controlled, but the phase composition after xerogel pyrolysis must be checked, as the temperature and the composition of the atmosphere of calcination have a significant impact on the apatite composition [22]. The long time, high energy consumption and cost of chemicals make the method expensive [25]. The wet precipitation is relatively simple and of low cost. The size of crystals and accordingly the specific surface area can be regulated by the synthesis conditions and additives over a wide range. The biggest crystals (up to hundreds of microns) with the highest regularity are obtained by the hydrothermal method. Nano-apatites are obtained at lower temperatures or the crystals growth may be controlled by functional organic additives. The hydrated ionic layer on the surface of the nanocrystals is a particular key feature of such low-temperature apatites, as the presence of water plays a major role in ion mobility and apatite processing [37, 38]. The product chemical composition must be carefully checked, especially in the case of synthesis of substituted apatites [39–42]. 4 Sorption, desorption and interactions mechanism on the apatite surfaces Reactions at the surface of apatite govern many biochemical processes and metal ions sorption has been proposed and studied for the purpose of environmental remediation. The surface reaction must also be considered when preparing ion-loaded apatites by impregnation. Sorption with apatite takes place by different processes depending on the environment and sorbent properties as well as on the apatite surface properties [43]. 4.1 Dissolution processes The dissolution process of apatites, which are thermodynamically very stable compounds, has been regularly studied from different points of view [44] and depends on the apatite chemical composition, solution pH and ionic composition as the presence of some ionic species may modify the apatite solubility by affecting the ion activity product. The incongruent solubility of apatites, particularly in weak solutions, is a property that must be considered in the case of sorption processes as well as congruent dissolution in solutions of pH ˂ 5. It is noted that alkaline-earth apatites (Ca2+, Sr2+, Ba2+…) are globally more stable than transition/post-transition metal apatites for a similar cation/P ratio and monovalent ion type (e.g. OH−): Ca∼x223CSr∼x223CBa > Mg > Mn(II) > Zn > Cd ∼x223C Fe(II) > Pb > Co(II) > Ni(II) > Cu [24]. The stability of rare earth elements like lanthanides substituted apatites was also studied [45]. 4.2 Re-precipitation processes The dissolution of Ap may cause precipitation of a new compound in moderately acidic and basic solutions that results in the sorption of cation from a solution at apatite surface [45] or formation of a new apatitic phase like Pb-pyromorphite or other phosphates [46]. 4.3 Cation exchange In solutions with a pH above 5, the cation sorption (mainly M2+ ions) is found to take place as a result of Ca2+ exchange. The apatite binding capacity depends primarily on the apatite surface properties but also on the solution composition and the cation congruity in the apatite structure [24]. The presence of dopants in the structure of Ap are significant not only for catalytic materials but also for the biochemistry of the Ap and environmental processes [41, 42, 44, 45]. 4.4 Molecular sorption Generally, the adsorption of molecules on apatitic calcium phosphates is considered to obey to electrostatic interactions but other surface reactions including ion exchange have also been proposed [47]. Molecule sorption also depends mainly on the apatite surface composition and charge, pH and composition of the environment and configuration of the molecule functional groups. Ca sites at Ap surface bind phosphate esters and other phosphorylated compounds (like bisphosphonates) [47–52], and compounds with sulphate, silicate or carbonyl groups [53]. 4.5 Synthesis of anion substituted apatites Depending on the apatite structure two type of anionic substitutions may occur in the monovalent anion position and in the phosphate group position. Well-known and studied is the exchange between OH− and F − anions, as well as CO3 2− substitution in the hexagonal axis and the impact of these changes on apatite stability and surface properties [23]. Carbonate and sulphate substituted Ca apatites are obtained by precipitation [14]. These substitutions lead to a lower stability than phosphate apatite. Arsenate and vanadate apatites (AsAp and VAp) can be derived from H3AsO4 and H3VO4 respectively [14] or synthesised at high temperatures [54, 55]. 5 Catalysts based on stoichiometric and non-stoichiometric calcium HAp There are few examples of calcium hydroxyapatites, whether stoichiometric or not, carbonated or not, used as catalysts for organic reactions, particularly for CC bond formation, this reaction beginning by the abstraction of a proton to give a carbanion intermediate. The main reason proposed is that HAp itself is supposed to possess only weak surface basicity and consequently it should be unable to promote the formation of a carbanion by abstraction of an acidic proton from the potential nucleophilic reagent (Scheme 1). Nevertheless, Sebti et al. [57] have shown that HAp can promote the Knoevenagel reaction at room temperature in neat conditions (Scheme 2). The synthesis of HAp used in this catalytic process was carried out by the hydrothermal method. The structure of the apatite was confirmed by X-ray diffraction, infrared spectra and chemical analysis. The surface area of calcined HAP was found to be SSA = 38.26 m2 g − 1. The total pore volume was calculated by the BJH method at P/P 0 = 0.98 (V T = 0.157 cm3g−1). Gruselle et al. using the hydrothermal method, have synthesised calcium HAp of different Ca/P ratio ranging from 1.44 to 1.68 with a SSA from 37.9 to 82.4 m2 g − 1 [56]. The X-ray diffraction of these materials show a typical apatitic structure for all the HAp obtained. They were found to be very efficient catalysts for the Michael CC bond formation. Deuterium labelling experiments have highlighted the role of the basic property of the surface (Scheme 3). Calcium HAp obtained by an aqueous precipitation-hydrolysis procedure having a stoichiometric Ca/P and a high SSA (120 m2 g − 1) was found to be an excellent catalyst for the hydrolysis of chlorobenzene at 375–450 °C to phenol [58]. The best catalytic performance was obtained from a high surface area (50–100 m2 g − 1), partially amorphous calcium phosphate apatite prepared by an aqueous procedure. The Ca ions can be isomorphously replaced with Sr, Ba, and the phosphate ions by arsenate ion, etc., to also yield active catalysts. The mechanism of the chlorobenzene hydrolysis reaction seems to be a nucleophilic displacement of the arylchloride by hydroxide with substantially complete retention of substituent position on the benzene ring. 6 Catalysts based on anionic modified apatites amongst the different anionic modifications described in apatite chemistry, for the sake of clarity, we focus on vanadate anionic VO4 3− substitution. The oxidative dehydrogenation of propane (Scheme 4) was investigated by Sugiyama et al. on vanadate catalysts supported on barium hydroxyapatite (VOx/BaHAp) [59]. The catalytic activities of VOx/BaHAp were compared to those on vanadate catalysts supported on calcium and strontium hydroxyapatites (VOx/CaHAp and VOx/SrHAp). The order of the activity was found to be VOx/SrHAp>VOx/CaHAp>VOx/BaHAp under the same reaction conditions. The results obtained from the reduction with H2 followed by the re-oxidation of these two supported catalysts reveal a stronger interaction of vanadate with SrHAp than with BaHAp. The oxidative dehydrogenation of propane to propylene was also investigated over vanadate catalysts supported on calcium and strontium hydroxyapatites (VOx/CaHAp and VOx/SrHAp) [60]. Catalytic activities were improved by both CaHAp and SrHAp supports, but the improvement was greater for VOx/SrHAp than for VOx/CaHAp. The maximum yield of propylene observed for 5% VOx/SrHAp was comparable to that of Mg2V2O7, which is one of the most active catalysts for the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane. The combination of active sites for loading (VOx) and the OH groups of the support (CaHAp and SrHAp) resulted in the enhanced catalytic activity. Furthermore, the redox nature of the loading directly contributed to the enhancement of VOx /SrHAp activity. The effect of catalyst wt. (5% VOx/SrHAp) relative to the feedstock flow rate on selectivities to propylene and COx suggested that oxidative dehydrogenation proceeded through a consecutive mechanism in which propylene was formed from the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane, followed by deep oxidation from propylene to COx, rather than the direct oxidation of propane. Kaneda et al. have reported the creation of monomeric vanadate species in an apatite framework and shown that this catalyst is active for Michael reaction in water (Scheme 5) [61]. The calcined VAp consists of three phases detected by Xray diffraction: CaO, a non-stoichiometric VAp Ca9(VO4)5(HVO4)(OH) on the surface and a stoichiometric VAp. After washing with hot water, the CaO phase disappears. The Ca/V ratio was found to be 1.5 confirming the non-stoichiometric character of the material obtained. According to the authors, the catalytic ability results in the formation of monomeric V-OH entities on the surface possessing a strong Brønsted basicity. Hara et al. have synthesised VAp containing VO4 3− species by a hydrothermal method. XRD, TEM, XPS, ESR, UV–vis DRS, V K-edge XAFS, 51 V MAS NMR, Raman spectroscopy revealed that the VAp obtained is non stoichiometric (Ca/V = 1.5), with the general formula Ca9(VO4)5(HVO4)(OH) [62]. According to the authors, this VAp possesses on the surface monomeric V-OH species with a strong Brønsted basicity. This strong basicity promotes the Michael reaction even in aqueous solvent. No vanadium leaching was detected during the above reactions, and the catalyst was readily recycled with no loss of activity. Metal vanadate-substituted hydroxyapatites (M = Ca, Sr and Pb) were prepared by Ogo et al. using the hydrothermal method and evaluated as catalysts for isopropanol oxidation to acetone [63]. The highest activity and selectivity to acetone were achieved with the Ca vanadate hydroxyapatite catalysts. M-vanadate hydroxyapatites (M = Ca, Sr, and Pb) with a single phase were synthesised at 110 °C for 14 h under the hydrothermal condition. The M-vanadate hydroxyapatite catalysts were column crystals with lengths of about 65–500 nm and widths of about 25–150 nm. The predominant catalytic function of all the prepared hydroxyapatites was to provide base catalysis for the reaction of 2-propanol. The acetone selectivity depended on the components of hydroxyapatite catalysts. In argon atmosphere, the acetone selectivity increased in the following order: Ca < Sr < Pb and vanadate < phosphate. The catalytic activities of M-vanadate hydroxyapatites were higher than those of M-phosphate hydroxyapatites except for Sr10(VO4)6(OH)2 catalyst, which decomposed during the reaction. The amounts of hydrogen produced were almost equivalent to the amounts of acetone produced over the Ca-Ap, Sr-Ap, Pb-Ap, and Pb-VAp catalysts, which had the strong basic sites. Calcium phosphate-vanadate apatites named (CPVAp) were synthesised by Maeda et al. according to different procedures [64]. The classical one developed by Boechat et al. [65] , which uses a hydrothermal method, leads to a material named CPVAp by the authors who claimed that it was efficient for the aerobic oxidation of propargylic alcohols. In contrast, the use of a VAp prepared according to Kaneda gave the oxidation product in moderate yield [61]. Sugiyama et al. have also tentatively synthesised fully VO4 substituted Hap (VAp) [66] following to the procedures reported by Mayer et al. [67] and Boechat et al. [65]. According to the authors, the first procedure leads to a precipitate which after calcination at 800 C was studied by X-ray diffraction. The XRD pattern does not agree with Ca10(VO4)6(OH)2 but rather with the oxy-vanadate Ca10(VO4)6O. This material was found not to have catalytic activity for the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane. Using the second procedure reported by Boechat et al. [65] a precipitate was obtained. The authors note that the Maeda work [64], claiming the formation, by this method, of a CPVAP is not supported by experimental results. Therefore, using the Boechat reported synthese, Sugyama et al. have obtained, by double precipitation, partially substituted VO4 Ap with V/P atomic ratio: 0.025, 0.05 and 0.10. XRD patterns of the obtained materials are consistent with an apatitic structure (Fig. 2 ) [66]. These catalysts incorporating vanadate in the HAp structure show an enhancement in catalytic activity for the oxidative dehydrogenation of alcohols compared to HAp. 7 Catalysts based on cationic modified apatites In this chapter, we will review the different apatites used as catalysts and whose composition has been modified by the presence of different cations, Na, Mg, Sr, La, Cr, Fe, Co, Rh, Ni, Pd, Pt, Cu Ag, Au, Zn, Pb, Bi, other than calcium in the apatitic structure. We will do this by following the position of these cations in the periodic table of the elements. In each case, we will describe the synthesis of the modified apatites obtained as well as their main structural and catalytic properties. 7.1 Ap containing group i element: Na Lamonier et al. have described the synthesis of HAp, stoichiometric or not containing Na+ and CO3 2− ions [68]. All the apatite syntheses were carried out using the co-precipitation method, in the absence or presence of CO2. Na ions were introduced by combining Ca(NO3)2 and NaNO 3 in a determined (Ca + Na)/P ratio. The catalysts were completely characterised (analysis, XRD, IR, thermal analysis and Specific Surface Area). The Specific Surface Area (SSA) is correlated with the concentration of CO3 2− anions in the structure. The XRD show that the materials obtained are consistent with a HAp structure, with slight changes in the a and c parameters according to the presence of Na+ and CO3 2− ions. These materials exhibit both acidic and basic properties related to their Ca/P ratio. According to the conversion of isopropanol to propene and acetone formation using the different apatites synthesised, the authors concluded that basic properties are correlated with an excess of Ca2+, while acidic properties result from a Ca2+ deficiency. The presence of HPO4 −ions is responsible for an increase in acidic sites. Addition of Na+ causes a moderate increase in basicity of HAp, while, introduction of CO3 2− ions enhance largely basicity. Thus, the addition of carbonate or sodium ions to the apatitic structure allowed the authors to enhance and adjust both the acidic and basic surface-properties leading to very efficient catalysts in the thiolation reaction of methanol. The best catalytic result was obtained using a slightly Ca-deficient Hap modified by Na+ and CO3 2− ions. 7.2 HAp containing group ii elements: Mg, Sr, Ba Ben Moussa et al. have obtained Mg2+ modified apatite MgHAp ((Ca+Mg)/P = 1.65) and tested them in the Biginelli reaction [69]. MgHAp were synthesised using the hydrothermal co-precipitation method. Powder X-ray diffraction indicates single phase and good crystallinity for the resulting material. All the peaks were indexed in the hexagonal P63/m space group. The SSA (20 m2 g − 1) is found to be low compared to HAp (82.3 m2 g − 1). The presence of a more acidic ion Mg2+ compared to Ca2+ enhances significantly the final yield of Biginelli product. Nevertheless, leaching of Mg2+ during the catalytic process is often a serious problem drastically limiting the use of such modified MgHAp as a catalyst. We earlier shown that, vide supra, in the second stage of the Raschig phenol process chlorobenzene is hydrolysed at 375–450 °C to phenol over a calcium hydroxyapatite catalyst [58]. In this reaction, the Ca ions can be isomorphously replaced with Sr, Ba, and the phosphate ions by arsenate ions, to also yield active catalysts. Copper (II) is a highly effective co-catalyst, while other transition metal ions are inactive. The mechanism of the chlorobenzene hydrolysis reaction seems to be a nucleophilic displacement of the arylchloride by hydroxide with substantially complete retention of substituent position on the benzene ring. Any benzyne component of this reaction is less than 5%. Ben Moussa et al. have synthetized Ba-, SrHAp and mixed CaSrHAp and BaSrHAp by a double decomposition method [70] and tested them in the Biginelli reaction [71] (Scheme 6). Powder X-ray diffraction indicates the formation of single phase with good crystallinity, indexed in the hexagonal P6/3 m space group. The SSA range from 7 m2 g − 1 for BaHAp to 44 m2 g − 1 for the mixed CaSrHAp. All these HAp have a M2+/P ratio close to the 1.67 stoichiometric one. The best results in the Biginelli reaction are obtained in methanol and attributed to the enhancement of OH− activity at the surface of the material. Ogo et al. [72] have reported the ability of SrHAp, namely Sr10(PO4)6(OH)2 and the solid solutions Ca10-ySry(PO4)6(OH)2 to catalyse selectively the conversion of ethanol to 1-butanol. The synthesis of the catalysts was achieved by the hydrothermal method and characterized by XRD, SSA and chemical composition. In each case the X-ray diffraction matched with a single phase having an apatitic structure. The M2+/P ratio is close to 1.67. The SSA of SrHAp and CaSrHAp were found to be 26.2 m2/g, which is lower than for the CaHAp used (58.7 m2/g). The preparation and characterization of a novel solid base catalyst hydroxyapatite loaded with strontium was described by Chen et al. [73]. The catalyst was obtained by calcining a porous HAp loaded with Sr(NO3)2 at 600 C. The obtained material was characterized by thermal gravimetric analysis, XRD, FT-IR, SEM, BET, SSA analysis and the Hammett indicator method. The results indicated an ion-exchange reaction. A new phase CaxSr1-xO was dispersed spontaneously onto the surface of the porous hydroxyapatite as a monolayer or sub-monolayer. The novel solid base catalyst catalysed the transesterification of soybean oil with the highest conversions of soybean oil being 85%. According to the authors, the catalytic activity of the transesterification could result from the new phase CaxSr1-xO. 7.3 HAp containing group iii elements: La In this part we consider the use of lanthanum ions to obtain La modified HAp catalysts. Mori et al. assumed that by using the cation exchange method, treating a stoichiometric apatite with La(Otf)3, an equimolecular substitution of Ca2+ by La3+ is possible, leading to an apatite substituted on the surface by La3+ (Fig. 3 ) [74]. The catalysts obtained starting from HAp or FAp are active for the Michael addition reaction and found to be better than the starting apatites. Priya et al. have obtained NaLaM3(PO4)3OH M = Ca, Sr, Pb and Ba by substitution of trivalent La ions on the formation of apatite structure [75]. The introduction of Na compensates for the depletion in positive charge due to the substitution of one trivalent La ion for two divalent Ca ions in Ca5(PO4)3OH hydroxyapatite. The catalysts obtained are found to be efficient in the Knoevenagel condensation. 7.4 HAp containing group vi elements: Cr, Mo Boucetta et al. have prepared chromium-loaded CrHAp catalysts starting from a HAp synthesised by the hydrothermal method, which was then mixed in aqueous media with a CrCl3 solution [76]. After mixing, the resulting starting pH is 4.8. At this pH, it is known that HAp, slowly releases only small amounts of Ca2+ and PO4 3− ions into the solution. Therefore, two mechanisms can occur: (i) an exchange of calcium and chromium ions. This hypothesis is the one of Boucetta; (ii) re-precipitation of the less soluble salt, according to the solubility product, in this case Cr(PO4)3, leading to a new phase. This hypothesis was evoked by some authors in the case of Ru - Ca exchange. The obtained materials were identified by several techniques including FTIR, Raman, XPS, UV–vis-NIR spectroscopies, EPR, X-ray and TPR. After calcination in air, several isolated chromium species were identified mainly on the surface of the HAp: Cr3+ ions, Cr5+ ions in low concentration and Cr6+ ions present as monochromates only at very low loadings (# 0.1 wt.% Cr) whereas, at higher Cr amounts (up to 3.7 wt.% Cr), Cr3+ species are preponderant. According to the author, the Cr3+ ions are mainly located on the apatite surface; they do not form Cr2O3 crystallites but isolated Cr3+–O–Ca2+ or Cr3+–O–Cr3+ entities at the highest Cr amounts. The CrCaHAp catalysts were tested in propane oxidative dehydrogenation in the 300–550 °C temperature range. The Cr6+ centres initially present on the catalysts may initiate the cracking of propane because of their acidity and improve the conversion. Isolated Cr3+ species are believed to be responsible for the propylene formation. Using the same synthetic method as Boucetta, Zhang et al. have obtained CrHAp catalysts [77]. The characteristics of these catalysts are very close to those described by Boucetta. In this case, the chromium loading in the catalyst was determined to be 4.6 wt% by ICP/AES and SSA of the CrHAP sample was found to be 50.12 m2 g − 1. These catalysts were successfully tested to produce 5-hydroxymethylfurfural from glucose. Production of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) from glucose was achieved in ionic liquids in the presence of hydroxyapatite supported chromium chloride (Cr-HAP) using oil-bath heating and microwave irradiation (MI). Compared with oil-bath heating, the MI method, clearly increased HMF yield and reduced the reaction time from days to several minutes. A maximum HMF yield of 40% was obtained from the dehydration of glucose under MI in 2.5 min. This method has potential as an energy-efficient and cost-effective approach for the conversion of biomass. In the same way, Lan et al. have synthesised chromium-exchanged hydroxyapatite encapsulated γ-Fe2O3@CrHAP (Scheme 7) [78]. The structure of the obtained catalysts was characterized by XRD, FT-IR, and XPS technologies. The catalysts were used in the conversion of carbohydrates into 5-hydroxymethylfurfual in DMSO. The catalyst could be easily separated by the application of an external magnet, and could be reused for several times without significant loss of catalytic activity. All the results dealing with molybdenum loaded HAp use an impregnation technique starting from a synthesised HAp, followed by mixing with a molybdenum salt in an aqueous medium. These results will be commented on Section 8. 7.5 HAp containing group viii elements: Fe, Ru Khachani et al. have synthesised FeHAp and used the obtained catalysts in butan-2-ol conversion and propane oxidative dehydrogenation [79]. First, a HAp was obtained by the classical hydrothermal precipitation method. The HAp shows an atomic ration Ca/P of 1.62, indicating a slight Ca2+ deficiency, with a SSA of 34.3 m2 g − 1. FexHAp catalysts with x ranging from 0.52 to 5.40 wt% were obtained by the ion-exchange method, mixing the HAp with a solution of Fe(NO3)3•9H2O in an aqueous medium. The precipitate obtained was dried at 80 °C then calcinated at 550 °C. It is important to note that the initial pH of the Fe3+ solution is 2.3. At this pH the HAp partially dissolve releasing Ca2+ and PO4 3− ions. All the data characterizing the obtained catalysts, XRD, IR, UV–vis, Mössbauer, XPS spectroscopies and temperature programmed reduction, are consistent with the presence of Fe3+ ions. This latter, responsible for the catalytic properties, were found to be present on the catalytic surfaces or in its vicinity. The efficiency of the FeHAp catalysts has been correlated with an enhancement of the acidic properties of the surface due to the presence of Fe3+ ions at the same time as maintaining basic ones. Using a similar synthetic procedure to that of Khachani et al. [79], Campisi et al. have obtained FeHAp where (Fe concentration ranges from 2% to 7% weight) and tested the obtained materials in the reduction of NO2 [80]. The FeHAp preparation employs the exchange procedure by mixing, for a short time, a HAp with an acidic aqueous solution of Fe(NO3)3 (pH = 3). According to the authors, the mixing time is the determining factor in preventing morphological damages to HAp and to insure a good dispersion of Fe3+ ions at the surface of the apatite. All the analysis and physical measurements reported support the presence of iron ions on the surface of the catalytic materials obtained. Ruthenium loaded apatites, named RuHAp, are widely used in oxidation reactions [81–89], especially of alcohols, but also in reduction reactions [90–92], depending on the oxidation state of the Ru entities which are present on the HAp. Three major synthetic methods are described in the literature [93]: Incipient Wetness Impregnation (IWI), Cationic Exchange (CEX) and Liquid Phase Impregnation (LIM), most often using ruthenium chloride RuCl3.nH2O in an aqueous solution. The nature of the ruthenium entities loaded and their link to the apatite is the subject of controversy on the part of the authors. In this section, we deal only with the RuHAp obtained by the exchange process and we discuss the nature of the catalysts thus obtained. In general, the procedure used consists of firstly the synthesis of a more or less stoichiometric HAp, followed by a more or less long contact of the latter with a RuCl3.nH2O salt in aqueous media. Subsequently, treatment involves calcination or not of the obtained material. In some cases, the Ru3+ moiety is reduced to Ru0. For Yamaguchi et al., the exchange between calcium and ruthenium ions is beyond doubt [83]. They proposed that the monomeric Ru species formed on the surface of a stoichiometric HAp is the catalytic entity in an efficient heterogeneous catalyst for aerobic alcohol oxidation. The authors, according to spectroscopic measurements, hypothesized that the Ru species on the surface of the RuHAP exists as a monomeric Ru cation surrounded by four oxygen and one chlorine atoms (Fig. 4 ). The authors concluded: "…the present simple preparation method using the cation-exchange ability of HAP can allow a strong protocol to create a monomeric metal species on the solid surface, as a hybrid heterogeneous catalyst.". Thus, the Ru3+ would be located essentially on the surface of the apatite and would be the centre of the catalytic process. Finally, Mondelli et al. give an interpretation where they propose the formation, consistent with Ca/Ru exchange, of RuOx entities on the surface of the apatite, as a new phase responsible for the catalytic process [82]. This is also our hypothesis [85], that of the constitution of a new phase, ruthenium rich, on the surface of the apatite. This phase arises by a process of dissolution/re-precipitation during contact between the apatite and the aqueous solution of RuCl3.nH2O, especially as the pH (1.86) of the medium is acidic and therefore favourable to the partial dissolution of the apatite and to the release of calcium and phosphate ions into the medium. Subsequently a re-precipitation process occurs ruled by the solubility product of salts which, according to the different ions present, can exist in this aqueous medium. Using the same preparation of RuHAp, Mori et al. have described the oxidation of silanes to silanols in good yields [84]. In other work, based on the same procedure to obtain RuHAp, and therefore on the same hypothesis concerning the Ca/Ru exchange process, Mori et al. described the efficiency of the RuHAp catalyst in Diels-Alder and Aldol reactions (Fig. 5 ) [94]. Wuyts et al. have synthesised a 2wt% RuHAp, using the exchange Ca/Ru method and starting from a non-stoichiometric apatite (Ca/P = 1.55) [95]. The authors assume that ruthenium is in a 3+ oxidation state and the ions are located on the apatite surface. Such a catalyst was found to be efficient in the racemization of secondary alcohols. Following the same procedure used by Yamaguchi to obtain RuHAp, d'Alenssandro et al. have shown the ability of such a catalyst to be efficient in the hydration of propargylic alcohols [96]. Mori et al. have perfected the RuHAp-based catalysts obtained by the Ru - Ca exchange method by adding a support based on Fe2O3 and allowing easy recovery of the catalyst by magnetic action [86]. This catalyst is effective in the oxidation of alcohols. The same iron oxide encapsulated by ruthenium hydroxyapatite was found by Zhang et al. [97] to be good heterogeneous catalyst for the synthesis of 2,5-diformylfuran. Yamaguchi et al. using RuHAP (9.1 wt%) described as a Ru(OH)x apatite supported, have shown the efficiency of this catalyst in the oxidation of alcohols [87]. Zhang et al. have studied and compared the catalytic activity of RuHAp and RuXHAp where X = F, Cl and Br obtained by the Ru/Ca exchange methodology, in oxidation of benzyl alcohol [88]. A particular order of activity was obtained as RuClAp > RuFAp > RuBrAp > RuHAp for the aerobic oxidation. The enhanced catalytic activities of RuXAp should be related to the electron-withdrawing effect of halogens as well as the structural and physico-chemical properties of the HAp surface and bulk modified by the addition of halogens. Peeters et al. have prepared the catalyst [98] using the standard exchange method [95]. The concentration of Ru depends on the desired weight percentage of immobilized ruthenium, which was fixed at 2 wt% as a standard. The catalysts obtained are found to be efficient in the amination of alcohols. 7.6 HAp containing group ix elements: Co, Rh According to the atomic radius in six fold coordination (79 pm) of Co2+ ion, compare to Ca2+ (114 pm), cobalt ion is not considered to be the preferred candidate in the Ca2+ - Co2+ exchange which can occur in apatites. Nevertheless, some authors have described the ability of Co2+ ions to replace, in low concentration, Ca2+ on the surface of apatites, and have taken advantage of this possibility to obtain cobalt modified apatites and used them as catalysts in particular in some oxidative processes. Sugiyama et al. have shown that strontium- and cobalt-strontium HAp are efficient catalysts in propane oxidation [99]. The catalyst was obtained from a SrHAp synthesised by the wet method and the Co2+ ions were incorporated by the impregnation technique. The obtained materials were calcined at 500 C. The maximum atomic ratio Co102/Sr was found to be: 5.47/16.3 (0.25 wt%). Spectroscopic measurements (XRD, 31P MAS NMR and XAF) allowed the authors to suggest that the materials obtained are a solid-solution: Sr10-xCox(PO4)6(OH)2. El Kabouss et al. have studied in details Cobalt-exchanged HAp in the oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane and 2-butanol [100,101]. The catalyst was obtained starting from HAp using the impregnation procedure. A complete characterization of the catalytic materials obtained shows that a limited amount of calcium ions can be exchanged by Co2+. At low Co2+ concentration (0.2 wt%), the exchanged ions exist as isolated Co2+ and are not oxidized in air at 823 K. For content > or = 0.4 wt% some cobalt oxides are identified and at Co2+ > or = 1.7 wt% the formation of Co3O4 nanocrystals oxide are identified. In summary, depending on the cobalt content the cobalt ions are present as isolated Co2+, CoxOy and Co3O4 (Fig. 6 ). This conclusion was shared by Carvalho et al. in the comparative studies of copper and cobalt modified HAp in conversion of glycerol to produce 1-hydroxyacetone [102]. Aellach et al. have also shown that from low stoichiometric apatites formation of Co3O4 entities on the surface of the HAp are more reducible than structural Co ions, the reduced Co0 being responsible for catalytic reduction processes [103]. Rakap et al. have also obtained Co0 nanoclusters supported on apatites prepared in situ from Co2+ adsorbed HAp obtained by impregnation, and used them for hydrogen generation from hydrolysis of sodium borohydride or ammonia-borane [104]. Phan et al. have synthesised Ni-CoHAp by successive impregnation of HAp [105]. Catalyst characterization is consistent with the existence of a partially cobalt and/or nickel exchanged apatite to a small extent as well as the presence of NiO and Co3O4 oxides new phases. All the prepared catalysts showed a good activity in the dry reforming of methane. Apatites are used as supports for Rh0 particles acting as catalysts in reduction reactions. Rh0 was loaded on apatites by means of an exchange between Ca2+and Rh3+ (atomic radius; 80.5 pm) ions followed by a reduction reaction of the pre-catalyst Rh3+HAp, leading to Rh0 nanoparticles located on the apatitic surfaces. The ionic exchange is obtained starting from a preformed apatite impregnated by a rhodium salt. Following this technique, Huang et al. described the formation of 1 wt% Rh supported HAp and its efficiency as a catalyst in the decomposition of N2O [106]. Özhava et al. have obtained 2.09 wt% Rh supported HAp (Fig. 7 ) [107]. The pre-catalyst Rh3+HAp and Rh0HAp reduced catalyst were fully characterized and the latter has been found to be highly active in hydrogen generation from the methanolysis of ammonia-borane. By the same method, Celik et al. have obtained Rh0HAp which is effective in hydrogen generation from hydrazine-borane [108]. Zahmakiran et al. have used such Rh0HAp in the solvent free hydrogenation of aromatic compounds [109]. In one case exchanged Rh3+FAp was used without reduction in the cross-coupling Baylis Hillman reaction. According to Kantam et al. [110] the proposed structure for RhFAp, as hypothesised by Yamaguchi for RhHAp [83] results from a Ca2+ - [Rh3+Cl] exchange on the surface of the apatite. Kantam has also observed that addition of 1–5 cod enhances the catalytic activity in the addition of organoboron reagents to α,β-unsaturated carbonyl compounds to yield conjugate-addition products. 7.7 HAp containing group x elements: Ni, Pd, Pt Nickel loaded hydroxyapatite NiHAp was obtained by two synthetic methods. i) by co-precipitation introducing the Ni2+ ions during the formation of the apatite ii) by the impregnation method, using a nickel salt. Using the co-precipitation technique Jun et al. have prepared catalysts for the partial oxidation of methane to syngas [111, 112]. The main result is that the different constituent phases of the catalyst obtained depend on the concentration of nickel ions. Only a small amount of the nickel ions loaded can be attributed to an exchange between Ca2+ and Ni2+ ions. At least three nickel species are present in the freshly prepared sample: calcium nickel phosphate, calcium nickel hydroxyapatite and nickel oxide NiO. The NiO phase becomes larger as the ratio Ni/PO4 increases. Under a reducing environment, during the reaction the NiO is reduced leading to metallic nickel. More of the catalytic activity was attributed to the Ni particles. Fan et al. have also used a co-precipitation technique to obtain NiHAp and Ni-H3PW12O40/nano-HAp containing 5 wt% Ni as an efficient catalyst for the hydrocracking of Jatropha oil [113]. The HPW Keggin structure was supposed to promote the reduction of Ni2+ to Ni0 due to an electron transfer from HPW to Ni2+. Another approach was developed by Boukha et al. [114] to obtain Ni loaded HAp and FAp used as catalysts in the dry reforming of methane. The catalysts were obtained by the Ap impregnation method of using aqueous nickel acetate solutions containing different amounts of nickel and the so obtained materials were finally calcined at 500 °C. The wt% of the loaded nickel ranged from 1 to 10%. The catalysts were completely characterized. The results allow to distinguish three types of nickel present on the HAp and Fap, their distribution depending on the quantity of nickel ions involved in the impregnation process. This result joins those described by Jun et al. [111, 112]. At low Ni concentration, above 2 wt%, nickel is present as Ni2+ exchanged with Ca2+ on the apatite, while in greater concentration the nickel exists as NiO in the form of large crystallites weakly bounded at the apatite surface or as small particles in strong interaction with the apatite (Fig. 8 ). Miniach et al. have obtained a NiHAp catalyst containing 14 wt% Ni starting from a commercially available apatite, by the impregnation method using Ni(NO3)2•6H2O in an aqueous medium [115]. This catalyst was modified by the addition of carbon nano-fibers which were grown by catalytic chemical vapour deposition using methane as the carbon source and then reduced by a hydrogen flow. In the reduction process it appears that two kinds of nickel are presents. One of them is the more easily reducible NiO phase located on the apatite surface the other is the nickel ions which migrate from the bulk to the apatite surface. Cichy et al. have studied the steam reforming of glycerol over deficient HAp supported nickel catalysts [116]. The calcium deficient HAp with a Ca/P = 1.57 ratio was synthesised under hydrothermal conditions. Nickel was introduced by the incipient wetness impregnation method, the nickel concentration ranging from 2.5 to 10 wt%. The materials obtained were calcined at 500 °C and reduced at 800 °C using hydrogen. The authors are in accordance with the interpretation of Jun [111] concerning the different state of the nickel particles located on the apatite support. Mesrar et al. have synthesised HAp starting from moroccan natural phosphate rock and loaded it with nickel by impregnation with an aqueous solution of nickel nitrate [117]. The obtained NiHAp catalysts, with a Ni concentration ranging from 2.5 to 10 wt%, were used in the production of hydrogen in the oxidation process of methane. As has been observed in all these types of impregnated HAp, a small part of the nickel is present as Ni2+ exchanged with Ca2+ in the apatite structure, whereas the major part exists as NiO located on the apatite surface. As catalysts based on palladium are used in many catalytic processes, Kaneda et al. [118] observed that: "Palladium is one of the most versatile catalyst metals in organic syntheses because of is unique catalytic performance for a wide-range of functional group transformations [119, 120]. Therefore, from the year 2002 to 2019, many articles have been devoted to the use of apatites as supports for palladium based catalysts. With the exception of a few articles which refer to a calcium / palladium exchange [121,122] most of the other articles, inspired by Kaneda's work, refer to an adsorption process at the surface of the apatite. Kaneda himself notes [118] "[…] isomorphic substitution of Pd for Ca did not occur in organic media, which is in sharp contrast to the RuHAP catalyst prepared by the cation exchange method in water." Therefore, the major part relevant to PdHAp will be commented on chapter 8. The literature on platinum-supporting apatites is often closely associated with that of palladium. In the examples available three methods are used to charge an Ap with platinum: Incipient Wetness Impregnation (IWI), Liquid Phase Impregnation (LPI) and Cationic Exchange (CEX). All the results described are in accordance with an adsorption of platinum onto the apatitic surface and therefore will be commented on chapter 8. 7.8 HAp containing group xi elements: Cu, Ag, Au Apatites modified with copper ions are obtained by reacting a HAp or FAp with a copper salt in an aqueous medium. All the authors refer to an exchange between calcium and copper ions and the copper content being around 5 wt%. Maaten et al. [123] and ben Moussa et al. [70] have synthesised catalysts starting from HAp of different compositions, using Cu(OAc)2 as the copper ion source. The obtained modified apatites are found to be efficient in the CC homo-coupling reaction of terminal alkynes and in the Biginelli reaction respectively. The authors found that the use of these catalysts is limited by the release of copper ion during the catalytic process. The same observation was made by Saha et al. [124] in the Sonoghashira CC coupling reaction where considerable leaching of the catalyst was found in the recovered catalyst after four cycles (Cu content in the fresh catalyst: 0.3237 mmol g − 1; Cu content after four catalytic cycles: 0.2127 mol g − 1) These authors have proposed a mechanism for this hetero-coupling reaction catalysed by CuHAp. Sun et al. [125] have synthesised catalysts based on apatites encapsulated in a magnetic support of Fe2O3 and supporting Cu0 nanoparticles (Scheme 8). This synthesis is carried out in two steps. The first consists of reacting HAP@γ-Fe2O3 with CuSO4 in an aqueous medium, the second is reduction with aqueous N2H4 leading to the formation of Cu0 nanoparticles on the surface of the apatite. The magnetic Cu0@HAP@γ-Fe2O3 nanoparticles are found to be an efficient catalyst for the one-pot three-component reaction for the synthesis of imidazo[1,2-a]pyridines. Choudary et al. have designed copper FAp and OtBuAp catalysts for N-arylation of heterocycles with chloro‑ and fluoroarenes [126]. Copper exchanged ions were introduced by reacting the apatite with Cu(OAc)2 in an aqueous medium. Reichle et al. studying the nature of the hydrolysis of chlorobenzene over calcium phosphate apatite have found that copper (II) is a highly effective co-catalyst, while other transition metal ions are inactive [58]. All the catalysts which are related to apatites modified by silver or gold will be treated in chapter 8, since they relate to the use of the mineral as a support for the metal catalyst considered. 7.9 HAp containing group xii elements: Zn There are few examples of using ZnHAp obtained by ion exchange techniques as catalysts. Zhang et al. have used Ru-Zn supported on hydroxyapatite as an effective catalyst for partial hydrogenation of benzene [127]. It was found that the addition of Zn to the RuHAp catalyst greatly increase the selectivity to cyclohexene formation. The catalyst was prepared by the ion exchange procedure consisting of the addition of an aqueous solution of RuCl3 and ZnSO4 to an aqueous suspension of HAp. After stirring, the recovered material was dried and reduced using pure H2, at 300 °C. The maximum amounts of Ru and Zn loaded were found to be 2.54 and 1.66 wt% respectively. The XPS spectrum showed that Zn2+ and Zn° coexist on the HAp surface. Riad et al. have studied the oxidative desulfuration of light gas oil using ZnHAp catalysts prepared either by wet impregnation or ionic exchange techniques [128]. The authors have described in details the different catalysts obtained by these two methods and clarified what materials are obtained from each. For the impregnated samples, the zinc content was found to be nearly the same as that introduced in the solution. According to Faria et al. [129], the zinc incorporation is limited to a value of 6–7%, possibly limited by the diffusion limit. On the other hand Miyaji et al. estimate at 15 mol% the limit of calcium substitution in the apatite network [130]. Using the impregnation technique there were no observed modifications in the X-ray diffraction, which means that there is no alteration of the apatite crystal lattice. On the other hand, when the Zn concentration increases, a new phase appears which was attributed to ZnO. In contrast, for materials obtained by ionic exchange techniques, the X-ray diffraction pattern showed a widening and a decrease in the intensity of the major diffraction peaks revealing a decrease in the crystallinity of the obtained material. According to Wakamura et al. [131] the growth of the apatite is restrained by the presence of divalent ions. On the other hand when the Zn concentration increases to 5.60 w% a new phase appears, identified as parascholzite: CaZn2(PO4)2•2H2O. Thus, the technique utilized for substituting the calcium of the apatite is of major importance in the structure of the catalyst obtained. The authors also attribute the best catalytic capacity to the material obtained by ion exchange and they attribute this result to a greater specific surface area, better porosity and the presence of paraschlozite. Ran Low et al. have obtained by co-precipitation technique ZnHAp as a catalyst for the decomposition of 2-propanol [132]. Low observes that little attention has been paid to the nature of the site of substitution of Ca ions by those of Zn and shows in this work that the CaT site is preferred to CaF. Kantam et al. have synthezized ZnHAp according to the wet impregnation procedure [133] developed by Mori et al. [134] who successfully used a ZnHAp, containing 0.3 mmol g − 1 Zn, as an efficient catalyst for the fixation of CO2 with epoxides. The ZnHAp obtained by Kantam was shown to be an efficient catalyst for the (2 + 3) cycloaddition of sodium azide with nitriles to afford 5-substituted 1H-Tetrazoles in good yiels. 7.10 HAp containing group xiv elements: Pb The oxidation of methane has been investigated by Sugiyama et al. [135] on lead hydroxyapatite (PbHAp), strontium hydroxyapatite (SrHAp) and their binary mixtures at 500 C. PbHAp showed no activity for the oxidation of methane, while SrHAp produced carbon monoxide selectively at 2–4% conversion. On binary mixtures of the hydroxyapatites the conversion of methane and the selectivity to C2 compounds reached values higher than those of the separate constituents of the mixture. With tetrachloromethane in the feed stream a similar synergistic effect was observed with conversions of methane and selectivities to CH3Cl higher on the binary mixtures than those on either SrHAp or PbHAp. The strontium-containing hydroxyapatite appears to play a crucial role in the activation of methane, while the presence of the lead-containing analogue is apparently required for the minimization of undesirable processes involving methyl radicals. 7.11 HAp containing group xv elements: Bi Sumathi et al. have synthesised the BiNaCa3(PO4)3OH apatite using the co-precipitation method [136]. Powder X-ray diffraction analysis of the compound synthesised indicates single phase and good crystallinity. Substitution of ‘Na’ and ‘Bi’ in the calcium site results in a slight increase in the c parameter and a negligible decrease in the a lattice parameter. The SEM picture indicates the formation of homogeneous product. BiNaCa3(PO4)3OH demonstrates its catalytic activity in the one-pot synthesis of dihydropyrimidin-2-ones. The increased efficiency of such calcium ion substituted BiNaHAp in the Biginelli reaction is correlated with the introduction of a more highly charged ion into the lattice enhancing the acidic property of the surface. Here, the introduction of Na+ cation plays a role in equilibration of the charges, according to 2 Ca2+ = Bi3+ + Na+. 8 Apatites as support for catalytic entities In Section 7, along in describing the catalysts obtained by substitution of calcium ions by metallic ions, by using either the technique known as impregnation or that of co-precipitation, we have seen that the limit is narrow between a true ion exchange and that where the ionic and / or metal oxide forms during the synthetic processes are new phases more or less bonded to the apatite. In Section 8, we will examine through a few examples the most frequently encountered situations: • Apatite as macro-ligand • Apatite as catalytic support 8.1 Apatites as macro-ligands According to Kaneda [137], the concept of apatite as a macro-ligand for catalytic entities is: "the development of highly functionalised heterogeneous metal catalysts based on the unique characteristics of natural inorganic crystallites, such as hydroxyapatite, as macro-ligands for active metal species. These catalysts show the concerto effect between metal active species and surface properties, and so are considered concerto catalysts" (Fig. 9 ). The concept developed by Kaneda serves as a general interpretation to explain the fixation of a transition metal ion by phosphate ions on the surface which then becomes the active catalytic centre of the apatite thus modified. 8.2 Apatite as catalytic support In chapter 7 we have described most of the catalysts based on apatites in which calcium ions are substituted by other metal ions using various experimental procedures ranging from co-precipitation to the impregnation of a previously synthesised apatite, by a solution of a salt of the metal ion which is to be introduced into the apatite. We have shown that the limit is often narrow between the competitive processes which can take place: substitution of ions, partial dissolution of the apatite and re-precipitation of different phases or quite simply deposition on the surface of the apatite. In this part, we will give some examples which concern the adsorption or the formation of a new phase on the surface of apatite. We can then speak of apatite as a support for the catalytic material. 8.2.1 HAp containing group iii elements: La Aissa et al. [138] have reinvestigated the process of substitution of Ca2+ by La3+ in HAp and FAp proposed earlier by Mori et al. [130]. According to this author, the structure of the catalytic entity was described as a monomeric LaIII complex, resulting from an exchange with CaII ions, surrounded by a hydroxyl OH− group, phosphate PO4 3- and weakly coordinated aqua ligands. Such results for lanthanum-modified Ap are very intriguing, especially since the substitution of La3+ ions for Ca2+ occurs to a very limited extent without penetrating into the apatite structure [124, 138–140]. Actually, as is the case for the action of RuCl3 with Ap [78], Aissa et al. found that the reaction between LaCl3 and Ap using the impregnation technique takes place mainly through partial dissolution of the HAp or FAp followed by precipitation of a new phase containing lanthanum phosphate [138]. Partial dissolution of Ap and leaching of phosphate ions is possible since the aqueous medium containing LaCl3 becomes acidic (Fig. 10 ). 8.2.2 HAp containing group vi elements: Mo Yuan et al. have synthesised catalysts based on MoHAp for epoxidation of olefins [141]. In these examples, the catalytic entity supported by the apatite is described as a molybdenum oxide Mox resulting from the calcination of the apatite obtained by the wet impregnation technique with a molybdenum salt. Moreover, the catalytic Mox entity is supported on hydroxyapatite-encapsulated γ-Fe2O3. Selective oxidation of methanol to formaldehyde was studied by Said et al. [142]. Chen et al. have used MoOx supported on HAp in the oxidative coupling of alcohols and amines to produce imines [143]. CoMoHAp and Ni-MoHAp have been used as catalysts for the desulphurization reaction by hydrogenolysis of dimethyldisulfide [144, 145]. 8.2.3 HAp containing group viii elements: Fe, Ru Chakraborty et al. have used biological apatites (fish bone) as the starting material for the synthesis of FeHAp [146]. The apatitic material was loaded using Fe2(SO4)3.H2O. The acidity of the aqueous medium during the loading process was not reported. XRD analysis show that the materials resulting from mixing the biological HAp and iron sulfate are a mixture of HAp, calcium phosphate Ca3(PO4)2, calcium iron phosphate Ca9Fe(PO4)7 and iron oxides FeO and Fe3O4. From these results, it is possible to say that no exchange process is occurring during the contact between HAp and iron sulfate. A new look at the ruthenium sorption mechanism on HAp an FAp was conducted by Tõnsuaadu et al. [85], using the wet impregnation technique based on RuCl3.nH2O reaction with apatites of different composition and stoichiometries in an aqueous medium. It was found, from all the analyses carried out, that in the reaction between RuCl3.nH2O and hydroxy, carbonate, or fluor apatite at pH 1.86, that a new Ru-rich solid phase is formed. This new phase located on the apatite surfaces appears to be a ruthenium hydroxy complex resulting from a partial dissolution of the starting apatite (Fig. 11 ). The amount of Ru bound on the apatite does not depend on its SSA. The RuHAp are more efficient catalysts than the RuFAp in the oxidation reaction of benzylic alcohol. This result is clearly in accordance with that published by Mondelli et al. [82] studying the efficiency of RuHAp in the aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol, the authors, according to spectroscopic measurements conclude that these results support the existence of a hydrated RuOx phase and this new phase coexists with isolated Ru3+ cations located in the accessible channel of the apatite. 8.2.4 HAp containing group ix elements: Co Jia et al. have obtained Co modified HAp using the impregnation technique, starting from an HAp and a Co(NO3)2 aqueous solution followed by a calcination at 600 °C and a reduction of the obtained material with H2 [147]. The high catalytic activity of Co/HAP could be due to its desired acidity, cobalt particle dispersion, and stronger metal−support interaction. The absorption of stearic acid on the surface of the catalyst which thus promotes the hydrogenation process over the Co species could also lead to a high yield of 1-octadecanol (Scheme 9). Shaabani et al. reported that natural hydroxyapatite (NHAp) supported cobalt tetrasulfophthalocyanine (CoTSPc-NHAp) can be used as a green, renewable and biomaterial-based heterogeneous catalyst [148]. This new heterogeneous catalyst mediates oxidation of various secondary benzylic C–H bonds, secondary benzylic and primary and secondary aliphatic alcohols to their corresponding aldehydes and ketones in high yields and selectivity without any additional oxidizing reagent. According to the authors the tetrasulfophthalocyanine is considered as a ligand and natural hydroxyapatite as a support leading to π-π stacking interactions of ligand (TSPc) and an electrostatic contribution of cobalt with NHAp as effective interactions in this heterogeneous catalyst. Mekrattanachai et al. have obtained a Co immobilized HAp with a low 0.05 wt% low concentration of Co by impregnation of an aqueous solution of CoSO4•7H2O on an apatite [149]. This catalyst is found to be efficient in alkene epoxidation under mild conditions. 8.2.5 HAp containing group x elements: Pd, Pt Essentially, the catalysts based on apatites modified with palladium are obtained by the impregnation method using the action of a palladium salt on an Ap. This impregnation step using Pd salts is followed by a reduction one, leading to Pd° forming nanoclusters on the surface of the apatite. The catalysts obtained containing Pd with concentration ranging from 0.75% [150] to 2% wt% [152] are used in different organic reactions including: CC bond formation, [150–155], hydrogen generation from the hydrolysis of ammonia-borane [156], hydrogenation of nitro compounds [157], oxidation of toluene [158], hydrogenation of phenol [159], alcohol oxidation [160–162], dehalogenation [163], dehydrogenation of indolines to indoles [164] and reduction reactions [165]. M. Pashaei et al. have developed, the use of γ-Fe2O3@HAp in order to separate easily the catalyst from the reaction mixture and additionally they demonstrated that the grafting of DABCO on the apatite surface, acts as stabilizer for the Pd nanoparticles (Scheme 10) [155]. Tang et al. have developed the OMSI concept (Oxidative Strong-Metal Support Interactions) between a platinum-group metal and HAp [166]. The Hap was synthesised by the co-precipitation method and after calcination, the Pd or Pt species were introduced by impregnation. According to the following references [167,168] the metal loading was found to be 0.22 to 0.61 wt%. The obtained materials were then oxidized at 500 °C. Physico-chemical studies suggested that the Pd or Pt species are highly dispersed, with a size of ≤ 2 nm on the HAp support. Rêgo de Vasconcelos et al. have studied the synthesis of hydroxyapatite supported ruthenium or platinum catalysts, and have investigated their catalytic performance in the transformation of methane and carbon dioxide into syngas [93]. Ruthenium and platinum on HAP support were prepared by three methods using RuCl3 and K2PtCl4 as metal precursors: Incipient wetness impregnation (IWI), cationic exchange (CEX) and excess liquid phase impregnation (LIM). SEM and TEM images of RuHAP obtained by the CEX technique show the formation of Ru particles indicating that crystallization or agglomeration of Ru-based compounds took place when HAP particles were in contact with RuCl3 solution. The expected cationic exchange between Ru3+ and Ca2+ did not happen or only partially. Miao et al. have explored the interdependence between apatite stoichiometry and the water gas shift (WGS) activity of such Pt catalysts by preparing HAP with Ca/P ratios ranging between 1.58 and 2.00, and a FAP [169]. Hydroxyapatite powders were synthesised by a precipitation method. Catalysts with nominally 1 wt% Pt were prepared by impregnation of the calcined apatite powders. The water-gas shift activity of PtAp catalysts is strongly correlated with increasing Ca/P ratio in the support material, until it levels of around Ca/P ≈ 1.75. The WGS performance is attributed to superior activation of H2O and stabilization of ensuing formate-like reaction intermediates on these hydrophilic ionic oxides. 8.2.6 HAp containing group xi elements: Ag, Au Wei et al. [170] have decorated apatite nanosheet-coated silica nanofibers with Ag nanoparticles (Ag-Ap-SiNFs). TEM images show that the surface of such obtained Ag-Ap-SiNFs is comprised of composites of Ap nanosheets with the thickness around 10 nm and AgNPs with the size of 5–20 nm. This catalyst was found as efficient by a superior photo-activity in the reduction of 4-nitrophenol in the presence of NaBH4. Pashaei et al. have synthesised silver nanoparticles on apatites supported on a magnetic core (γFe2O3@HAp) [171]. The attachment of DABCO to the apatite surface facilitates the formation of silver nanoparticles on the surface and then stabilises them. All the physico-chemical data confirm the presence of DABCO and silver on the surface of the apatite. The catalyst obtained is effective in the reduction in aqueous medium of nitroarenes in the presence of NaBH4. Das et al. in a method similar to that of Pashaei [171], use the formation of polydopamine on the surface of an apatite, as a reducing reagent in the transformation of silver ions to silver nanoparticles which constitute the active part of the catalyst in the reduction of 4-nitrophenol [172]. Silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) were gradually grown on a hydroxyapatite surface via a self-reducing approach. HAp was functionalised by dopamine and subsequently self-polymerised onto the HAp surface. Surface-adhered polydopamine acted as a self-reducing agent for the Ag+ ion. The nanoparticles were evaluated by UV–visible spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction, scanning electron microscopy, transmission electron microscopy, and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy. The characterisation data revealed that the AgNPs were spherical and crystalline, with an average size of 14.79 nm (Fig. 12 ). Xu et al. have prepared highly dispersed silver nanoparticles supported on a hydroxyapatite showing a high activity and selectivity for the oxidative dehydrogenation of ethanol to acetaldehyde [173]. The preparation of the catalyst was achieved in three steps: preparation of HAp by the precipitation route followed by the addition of a methyl cellulose solution and finally introduction of the silver by the impregnation method using an AgNO3 solution (0.5% wt) The structure of the Ag nanoparticles was characterized using (TEM), X-Ray Diffraction (XRD), in-situ and ex-situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and temperature-programmed surface reaction (TPSR). Mitsudome et al. have shown that hydroxyapatite-supported (AgHAP) acts as a highly efficient reusable heterogeneous catalyst for hydration of diverse nitriles, including heteroaromatic ones, into amides in water [174]. The preparation of the catalyst proceeds in two stages: obtaining the apatite by precipitation, followed by impregnation with an aqueous solution of AgNO3 and then reduction with NaBH4. TEM observations show the formation of silver nanoparticles, with a size of 7.6 nm on the surface of the apatite. Kumar et al. have synthesised a novel and high-performance silver loaded hydroxyapatite (HAp) catalyst for the selective catalytic reduction of NOx by propene [175]. The catalysts with variable silver content have been prepared and characterised extensively by different techniques such as XRD, XPS, BET-surface area, TPR, TPD and ICP analyses. The catalytic activities were measured at reaction temperature ranging from 250 to 500 °C. The 1.5 wt% AgHAp was found to be the best amongst all the catalysts studied showing about 70% conversion and 60% selectivity towards N2 formation at 375 °C in oxygen rich atmosphere. Apatites are widely used as a support for gold nanoparticles. The AuHAp catalysts are obtained by the impregnation method from an apatite and gold salts in aqueous solution, this step being followed by the reduction of the gold ions and leading to nanoclusters of Au0. The use of HAp as a support makes it possible to avoid sintering of the gold particles. Guo et al. [176] note that the Au-TiO2 HAp composite catalyst is more efficient than that of Au-TiO2, precisely because the apatite contributes to reducing sintering. Sreedhar et al. have shown that the addition of Gum Acacia during the preparation catalyst modifies the crystal growth while at the same time serving as a reducing agent for Au3+ ions, leading to gold nanoclusters of 3–13 nm on the surface of the apatite [177]. Wang et al. hypothesized that the origin of the stabilization of gold clusters is due to the interactions of gold ions with the phosphate and hydroxyl groups on the surface of the apatite [178]. Essentially, the catalysts obtained are used in oxidation reactions. 8.2.7 HAp containing group xii elements: Zn Solhy et al. [179] as well as Tahir et al. [180] have reported the use of HAp and FAp as a support for ZnCl2 and ZnBr2 in transesterification as in the Michael addition reactions. The preparation of the catalyst proceeds by the prior synthesis of HAp and FAp by the precipitation method followed by calcination of the apatite. The zinc salts are introduced to the apatitic support by the impregnation method from aqueous solutions of these salts. The X-ray analyses confirm the classical structure of the HAp and FAp. In both cases there is no evidence for the presence of a ZnX2 phase (X = Cl, Br). The authors attribute this to the high dispersion of ZnX2 on the surface of the apatite. 8.2.8 HAp containing group xiii elements: Al Starting from an apatitic material obtained from waste cooked fishbone and further doped with aluminium ions by the wet impregnation technique using an aqueous solution of Al(NO3)3.9H20 as the Al ions source, Sahu et al. have obtained an Al doped HAp [181]. After calcination at 650 °C, the formation of Al2O3 nanoparticles was observed. TEM analysis confirms the self-assembled structure of the HAp and Al2O3. The obtained material was used for neem oil transesterification. The reusability highlights the chemical stability of the catalyst. Rahmanian et al. have prepared a modified apatite for the catalysis of the dehydration of ethanol into diethyl ether [182]. This Al ion doped apatite was obtained by the wet impregnation route using a solution of Al(NO3)3•9H2O as a source of aluminium ions and a non-stoichiometric Ca/P = 1.62 HAp. After calcination at 600 °C, the recovered powder was found to have a Al/Ca ratio of 1.07 and a (Ca+Al)/P mol ratio of 1.62. X-ray showed the presence of two phases: an apatitic phase and an AlPO4 phase. The AlPO4/HAp catalyst was found to be more active than HAp in the dehydration of ethanol to diethyl ether. 9 Concluding remarks If the industrial chemistry of apatites is largely devoted to the production of fertilizer, thanks to their cationic exchange properties they also play an important role in environmental remediation. Apatites are used in trapping metal ions in wastewater due to their ability to insolubilize these ions in the form of phosphates, these insoluble phases being easely removed from the polluted medium. Biological apatite has received considerable attention in the fields of medicine and dentistry. In the lasts decades while the use of apatites as catalysts has been the subject of much work, much remains to be done to have a comprehensive understanding of the catalytic processes involved. Given the diversity and qualities of apatites as catalysts or catalytic supports, one of the trends in this chemistry will certainly be its development in the industrial field. Throughout this review we have tried to highlight the versatility of apatite-based materials as catalysts or catalytic supports covering a wide spectrum of chemical reactions (Tables T1-T4). This capacity of apatites is largely correlated to their chemical composition and their structure as well as to the consequences of their acid-base surface properties. At the same time, the capacity of apatites to accept changes in anionic and cationic composition and correlatively in structure make the analysis of the catalytic materials obtained in these transformations complex. Thus, the border is sometimes held between a true anionic and/or cationic substitution within the structure of the apatite with substitutions limited to the surface, a simple adsorption or even the formation of new phases during the process of synthesis of the catalytic material. This is especially true when using impregnating techniques starting from a pre-synthetized apatite. Unfortunately, often few attention is paid on complete characterisation of the material used that makes complicated to compare different materials and their effectivity. Thus, there remain many controversies surrounding the nature of the materials obtained by impregnating a salt containing metal ions capable of replacing the calcium ions in the structure or on the surface of the apatites. The results are not always clearly established and leave some doubt as to the real nature of the catalytic entities obtained. It is therefore necessary to be very attentive to the operating methods used and critical of the physicochemical results presented. coredata.dc:description: This review focuses on apatite based catalysts, which are widely used in a large spectra of chemical reactions: oxidation, reduction, formation of CC, CO, C-S, and CN bond, cycloadditions and multi-component reaction. Up to date reviews were mainly devoted to the catalysed reactions themselves, which were described in details. Nevertheless, the intimated nature of the catalysts used, which are obtained from various preparation techniques has deserved less attention. This review is a first tentative classification of the apatite based catalysts where stoichiometric or not apatites as well as modified ones by cation or anion substitution in their structure or surface, act as catalyst, as well as apatites acting as catalyst support. In each case the specific role of the apatite as well as the synergic effect between the catalytic entity and the apatitic support will be discussed.
coredata.dc:title: Apatites based catalysts: A tentative classification
